Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Non-genomic Androgen Receptor Mechanisms Involved in Social Regulation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Part 1: This research will examine how steroid hormones, which are produced by all vertebrates, directly activate receptors on the surfaces of neurons in the brain to influence behavior. Once activated, these receptors rapidly change the internal responsiveness of those cells to incoming sensory inputs and thus alter an organism's perception of the world around it. Determining if steroids work through such mechanisms will help us better understand basic hormone signaling mechanisms as well as the complex neurochemical processes that enable animals, including humans, to adjust their behavioral responses to constantly changing social environments. The experiments will contribute to the training of our nation's future scientists, educators and doctors through the hands-on research experiences that will be provided for students at an exclusively undergraduate institution. Students will participate in projects related to the award through a lab course run by the PI as well as through focused independent research experiences in the PI's lab. The PIs will recruit students from diverse socioeconomic and racial backgrounds to participate in the research. Additionally, the PI will promote STEM education on a Native American reservation in Maine through a neuroscience workshop.

Part 2: Although non-genomic androgen receptor signaling mechanisms have been well-documented in the peripheral tissue of a variety of vertebrates their rapid, central influences have not been thoroughly examined. This project will investigate a novel mechanism through which androgens may rapidly affect social behavior in male goldfish. The goals of this project are to assess whether 1) testosterone rapidly promotes courtship in competitive contexts through androgen receptors; 2) androgen receptors rapidly modulate courtship by influencing responses to pheromones; and 3) androgen receptors affect early olfactory processing and/or functional coupling across brain networks. By characterizing a novel mechanism through which androgens rapidly modulate the processing of social stimuli, new insight into the fundamental neuroendocrine signaling mechanisms that allow animals to rapidly adjust their behavioral responses to constantly changing social environments will be potentially revealed. This project will also have two major types of broader impact. First, it will directly enhance the scientific education of undergraduates at Bowdoin College by integrating the proposed research into an existing neuroscience laboratory course and through independent summer internships and honors projects. Second, the PIs will continue a 4-day workshop in northern Maine for Native American 7th grade students that is built around this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our work focused on how androgens like testosterone and estrogens like estradiol rapidly influence prosocial and antisocial responses in vertebrate animals. Traditionally, we know these hormones activate receptors inside of cells that turn genes on and off and, as a result, slowly change the proteins produced by those cells. In the brain, it often takes hours, if not days to weeks, for enough changes in protein levels to accumulate in cells to change the behavior of the animal. In contrast, our work focused on how these hormones can activate receptors on the surface of neurons that can, within seconds to minutes, change the physiology of those cells and thus more dynamically modify the behavior of the animal. Specifically, we demonstrated that testosterone can, within 20 minutes, promote affiliative social responses towards partners and siblings, as well as increase aggression towards rivals, in male and female gerbils, and that it likely does so by activating cells in the brain the produce and release oxytocin. These results were remarkable for not only showing that testosterone, often considered a male hormone, can produce similar effects in both sexes on rapid timescales, but also that it can promote positive, prosocial responses that are not sexual, as well as aggressive behaviors, depending on the social contexts present when it is elevated. Thus, testosterone may not simply promote specific behaviors, but rather promote whatever social response may be most appropriate in a particular social context. In another set of experiments done in zebrafish, the hormone typically thought of as a female hormone, estradiol, enhanced social approach responses towards groups of fellow zebrafish within one hour. Again, this result demonstrates that this “female-hormone” also has rapid, prosocial effects in both sexes that allow it to modulate, at least in species that live in groups, how social animals are with other individuals in the group. Together, our work in these two species with two different steroids demonstrates that these molecules are not simply male or female hormones that always produce the same effects on social behaviors, most notably their well-documented ability to increase aggression, but rather that each can dynamically influence multiple types of social responses in both sexes that can, in some contexts and/or in some species, make animals more or less likely to engage in social interactions with the other animals they live with.  

Importantly, much of this work was conducted by undergraduate students in lab courses and through independent research opportunities, thereby contributing to the training of our nation’s future medical professionals and scientists. Further, we extended our research with fish into an ongoing outreach experience for 7th graders on a Native American reservation in northern Maine, thus providing opportunities for hands-on scientific research experiences not typically available to such students.
